Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Add additional text to use of online safety categories in report package form" (#8899) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Add this text above the details box when a safety category is chosen:

Please also describe where in the package the problem was found. 

Be sure to include:
-	Whether the problem is in graphics, video, readme, scripts, libraries, nuspec, other metadata, other file(s).
-	The exact names of the offending file(s).


/cc @jcjiang

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[NuGet.org Bug]: Add open.vscode.dev to allowed domains for images and badges" (#8898) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Describe the bug

The open.vscode.dev domain is not included in the list of [allowed domains for images and badges](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/nuget-org/package-readme-on-nuget-org#allowed-domains-for-images-and-badges) for package readme files. This breaks loading "_Open in Visual Studio Code_" badges, with only the alt text being displayed. It's a minor cosmetic issue, but if there's no security concerns it would be nice to have the domain added to the allow list. It is a Microsoft owned domain.

### Repro Steps

Upload any package with an included readme and an _Open in Visual Studio Code_ badge referencing the open.vscode.dev domain.

### Expected Behavior

Loads the _Open in Visual Studio Code_ badge.

### Screenshots

Current:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3214803/144153559-ee29caaf-d01c-4483-8a20-05b820db1173.png)

Desired:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3214803/144153625-4e6173ca-5d65-4aaa-9cba-931ff24f8fd2.png)


### Additional Context and logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Feature]:  Syntax Highlighting for code example in Readme.md" (#8894) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Related Problem

The code examples on .nuget have no syntax highlighting. In some case this might be confusing for users.


### The Elevator Pitch

Add Syntax Highlighting for code examples at readme.md. (Like the one here on github)

### Additional Context and Details

Example:

 C# Code:
```C#
public class Foo {
  public string GetBar() => "bar";
}

```

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Bug]: weird NU5128 error for a runtime-only package" (#11415) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

dotnet.exe

### Product Version

.NET SDK 3.1.415

### Worked before?

.NET SDK 3.1.116

### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Repro Steps & Context

We have a `MyProject.RuntimeOnlyDeps.nuspec` file inside a `MyProject.RuntimeOnlyDeps` folder with a `MyProject.RuntimeOnlyDeps.csproj` that targets  `netcoreapp3.1` and that is needed to deploy some assemblies to the build output that need to be loaded by the app but should never be added as reference to the consumer of our nuget packages.

`MyProject.RuntimeOnlyDeps.nuspec` has the following content.

```xml
<?xml version="1.0"?>
<package xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/packaging/2010/07/nuspec.xsd">
  <metadata>
    <id>MyProject.RuntimeOnlyDeps.nuspec</id>
    <version>1.2.3456</version>
    ...
  </metadata>
  <files>
    <file src="_._" target="ref\netcoreapp3.1" />
    <file src="bin\Release\netcoreapp3.1\Contoso*.dll" target="lib\netcoreapp3.1"/>
  </files>
</package>
```

When we pack using `dotnet pack MyProject.RuntimeOnlyDeps.csproj` with SDK 3.1.116 or SDK 3.1.415 (no difference here) we get the following errors:

> error NU5128: Some target frameworks declared in the dependencies group of the nuspec and the lib/ref folder do not have exact matches in the other location. Consult the list of actions below: 
> error NU5128: - Add a dependency group for .NETCoreApp3.1 to the nuspec [c:\build\_work\342\s\src\MyProject.RuntimeOnlyDeps\MyProject.RuntimeOnlyDeps.csproj]

Can this error be solved? If so, how?  I don't see how I could "add a dependency group for .NETCoreApp3.1 to the nuspec" in this case.

Furthermore, on the Azure Devops Server build pipeline we have `WarningsAsErros` enabled. There with SDK 3.1.116 the build did not break despite the aforementioned errors. with SDK 3.1.415 however, the build suddenly breaks. Why this change in behavior?  Was it just a bug in SDK 3.1.116 ?
 

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Bug]: Cannot get INuGetProjectService from the service broker in Visual Studio 17" (#11367) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

MSBuild.exe

### Product Version

Visual Studio 17.0.0

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

I'm unable to use this version

### Repro Steps & Context

An exception is thrown in Visual Studio ~~2017~~ 2022 when trying to get an `INuGetProjectService` from the Visual Studio service broker. This code:
```cs
var serviceBrokerContainer = await ServiceProvider.GetGlobalServiceAsync<SVsBrokeredServiceContainer, IBrokeredServiceContainer>();
var serviceBroker = serviceBrokerContainer.GetFullAccessServiceBroker();

// This next line throws the exception.
var projectService = await serviceBroker.GetProxyAsync<INuGetProjectService>(NuGetServices.NuGetProjectServiceV1);
```
Throws this error in Visual Studio 17.0.0:
> Activating the "Microsoft.VisualStudio.NuGet.NuGetProjectService (1.0)" service failed.
> Unable to cast object of type 'NuGet.VisualStudio.Implementation.Extensibility.NuGetProjectService' to type 'NuGet.VisualStudio.Contracts.INuGetProjectService'.

The package references I'm using are:
```xml
<PackageReference Include="Microsoft.VisualStudio.SDK">
  <Version>17.0.31902.203</Version>
</PackageReference>
<PackageReference Include="NuGet.Protocol">
  <Version>6.0.0</Version>
</PackageReference>
<PackageReference Include="NuGet.VisualStudio">
  <Version>6.0.0</Version>
</PackageReference>
<PackageReference Include="NuGet.VisualStudio.Contracts">
  <Version>6.0.0</Version>
</PackageReference>
```

I'm also seeing a warning about the version of `Microsoft.ServiceHub.Framework` not being found. Could this be related? It seems like the `NuGetProjectService` returned from the service broker is implementing the `INuGetProjectService` interface from a different assembly to the one I am expecting.

Using this project file:
```xml
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">
  <PropertyGroup>
    <TargetFramework>net6.0</TargetFramework>
  </PropertyGroup>
  <ItemGroup>
    <PackageReference Include="NuGet.VisualStudio.Contracts" Version="6.0.0" />
  </ItemGroup>
</Project>
```
Restoring packages gives this warning:
> NU1603 NuGet.VisualStudio.Contracts 6.0.0 depends on Microsoft.ServiceHub.Framework (>= 2.7.327-preview) but Microsoft.ServiceHub.Framework 2.7.327-preview was not found. An approximate best match of Microsoft.ServiceHub.Framework 2.7.339 was resolved.

`Microsoft.ServiceHub.Framework 2.7.327-preview` is [not listed on NuGet](https://www.nuget.org/packages/Microsoft.ServiceHub.Framework/).

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Bug]: Some packets are pushed very slow to nuget.server" (#11420) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

MSBuild.exe, NuGet.exe

### Product Version

nuget.exe 5.11.0.10, msbuild  16.11.1.47101, nuget.server 3.4.1.0

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Repro Steps & Context

1. step one: create some nupkg packages using msbuild xml.  The following code is used to build the package

`<MSBuild Projects="$(BuildSolutionDir)/Mares.Scheduler.Api.Client/Mares.Scheduler.Api.Client.csproj" Targets="Restore" />
<MSBuild Projects="$(BuildSolutionDir)/Mares.Scheduler.Api.Client/Mares.Scheduler.Api.Client.csproj"
				 Targets="Build;Pack"	Properties="Configuration=$(Configuration);PackageOutputPath=$(NuGetPackageDir);Authors=$(Authors);Version=$(Version)" />`


2. step two: push packages with a powershell script to nuget server (hosted in iis 10).  some package need 250ms to be pushed, other need more than 30sec.  The following is the code I use to push the package

`$PackagePath = "$(Get-Location)\Packages"
Get-ChildItem $PackagePath -Filter *.nupkg|
Foreach-Object {
    Invoke-Expression "$($NugetPath) push $($_.FullName) -Source $($NugetApi) -ApiKey $($NugetApiKey) -Verbosity detailed" 
    Remove-Item $_.FullName
}`

The strange behaviour occur when publishing new packets and when replacing existing packets.  It looks like nuget server rebuild some cache


### Verbose Logs

```shell
NuGet Version: 5.11.0.10
Pushing Mares.Scheduler.Api.Client.3.0.2.nupkg to 'http://192.168.34.200:81/api/v2/package'...
  PUT http://192.168.34.200:81/api/v2/package/
  Created http://192.168.34.200:81/api/v2/package/ 45121ms
Your package was pushed.
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[DCR]: Obsolete VS extensibility APIs that use System.Runtime.Versioning.FrameworkName" (#11419) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Affected

NuGet SDK

### Current Behavior

`IVsFrameworkCompatibility`, `IVsFrameworkCompatibility2` and `IVsFrameworkParser` all use `System.Runtime.Versioning.FrameworkName`, which is suitable to parse the MSBuild property `TargetFrameworkMoniker`. However, since .NET 5 introduced `net5.0-windows` as a target framework, this is now a combination of MSBuild `TargetFrameworkMoniker` and `TargetPlatformMoniker`. The BCL's `FrameworkName` cannot handle this, making all platform specific target frameworks indistinguishable from the no-platform target framework.

### Desired Behavior

VS extension developers using these NuGet APIs should update to newer versions of the interfaces which use `IVsNuGetFramework`, which has fields for both `TargetFrameworkMoniker`, and `TargetPlatformMoniker` (plus `TargetPlatformMinVersion`, important for UWP projects)

### Additional Context

_No response_
